pros: Good work life balance Fantastic colleagues Innovative and positive environment

pros: Learn a lot International diversity

review_title: Great place to do a PhD
pros: Compared to other universities around the world, doing a PhD in a Dutch university it is a much better experience because you are valued as an employee and not just a student. Vrije is also great because they have good experience with international students so they are there to help you with everything before and after the PhD as well. The amenities as an employee (gym, cafeteria, social gatherings, etc) is outstanding.
cons: There is one thing you should know before taking the role. You are asked to do teaching and supervision, which depending on the department/supervisor can be a lot or not that much.

pros: - Friendly, helpful and understanding superiors - Free coffee/printing - Access to offices
cons: - The salary is low compared to TA jobs at other universities

pros: 1. Great workload balance for a part-time job. 2. Dynamic and flexible arrangement of schedule and work. 3. It is easy to ask for help and support when in confusion. 4. Considerably good salary given the manageable workload.
cons: 1. The entire TA position is not very organized, but they are taking this problem seriously and actively improving on this aspect. 2. It could be very tiring dealing with students' questions even after working hours.

pros: Work is fun, and the pay is good for the hours you make
cons: Workload is heavily skewed towards grading weeks

pros: management, work from home, flexibility
cons: none come to mind at the moment

pros: flexible working hours, nice team
cons: relatively low salary for an expensive city like Amsterdam

review_title: Great place to work as a side job
pros: Good pay Nice colleagues Flexible hours
cons: Gets tedious over time no real growth

pros: Each student with good grade can apply for.
cons: Hardly any cons for now.

review_title: good university, but situation depends on department
pros: good benefits, fairish pay and striving to become better
cons: research everywhere can be pretty hard on mental health. here is no exception

pros: Grateful for all the support

pros: 40 days of holiday annually

pros: free coffee free printing flexible

pros: very nice environment to work at

pros: 40 vacation days, a friendly atmosphere

pros: You get a lot of freedom and work with nice colleagues.

pros: It is located in Amsterdam.
cons: Unprofessional and rude staff. Havoc of an organization. God forbid you have a problem to solve. Zero support for the teaching staff. Zero accountability, and unsupportive and incompetent supervisors. You didn't get a PhD to work in this dumpster. Find a job somewhere else.

pros: Good salary, its fun, open for learning.

pros: good salary, meet with professors

review_title: Happily doing my PhD at VU
pros:
Very convenient location (close to Zuid station)
Beautiful offices if you work for the School of Business and Economics and are located in the main building
This is probably dependent on each department: Flexible regarding working from home, overall staff is very friendly
cons: I am overall very pleased doing my PhD at the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam. They could replace desktop computers against laptops, but the Covid-19 crisis may have this effect anyways.

pros: freedom to do what I want
cons: The university is internationally not competitive.

pros: Compact and reachable campus, diverse student body, teaching can be very rewarding
cons: Large amounts of bureaucracy even compared to other universities, anything involving centralized departments is usually a multi-month nightmare

pros: High flexibility in my reserach position.
cons: Cannot really say sth. negative here.

pros: Research is good, nice environment
cons: No pay for internships, too bad

pros: nice work environment and colleagues

review_title: Review about my last postdoctoral research activity
pros: Highly prestigeous research group with huge number of publications. High standard is required and expected from applicants. The financial support is excellent. State-of-art laboratories and measuring setups enable to pursue high-quality research.
cons: The research group was too large. The scientific output was not proportional with the number of group members. The technical assistance of the research was not organised well, therefore the research projects based on experimental work is hardly feasible.

pros:
- Met some amazing people while in Amsterdam; fantastic international students
- In-depth coursework on all kinds of topics
 - Great professors
- Plenty of research opportunities
cons:
- Courses are super short (4wks-2months; some may find this a plus, but for someone used to a 4 month semster, this was crazy for me)
- Because the city is so amazing, you'll be hard-pressed to become a workaholic - or want to work at all

review_title: Great infrastructure, great support staff, lots of holidays.
pros:
Great community feeling, while doing top notch research at the same time.
Many collaboration opportunities, flexible time management as well as End-of-year and Holiday bonuses.
320 hours of vacation per year
cons:
All the paperwork is mostly in Dutch, so foreign employees often struggle with filling the various administrative forms in. However the support staff is always willing to help.
The campus is located outside the city center, but it is not difficult to reach via public transport or bicicle

pros:
- you can plan an decide on your own research
- knowledgeable staff 
- there is room for making mistakes and learning from them
cons:
- you really have to be proactive to get what you need
- it has a very individualistic culture
- course load can be very high
- you have to teach at one point, but you will get very little guidance.

review_title: Good  place to work but very difficult to integrated as a foreign national with Dutch environment
pros: flexible working hours, room to make mistakes and learn form them, easy access by public transport, world call research
cons: teaching pressure, you have to be highly individualistic - no one to help you with teaching duty.

pros: Very modern workplace, lots of interaction and completely digitalised and paperless. Free work culture, many paid vacation days.
cons: Salaries for academic personnel (dentists) not competitive in comparison with private practice. Lack of resources for personal development. Chaotic management.

pros:
Lots of freedom to plan your own time and work.
Professional atmosphere.
cons: Sometimes a bit too bureaucratic to get things easily done. As with many universities, money or funding is never present in abundance, and a big recurring side-task is always to find new ways to keep things (and yourself) funded.

pros:
- Hierarchy is pretty flat
- Academic freedom
- Tenure-track is pretty easy (not as the US style)
cons:
- Low salary compared to Amsterdam industries
- Spoiled students
- Office too often empty (a lot of people working remotely), you may have difficulty to collaborate
- Dutch funding requires industry collaborations

review_title: Great place to study and work part-time
pros:
Flexible working schedule.
Low levels of stress.
intelligent colleagues
cons: Not very high pay, but very good as a part time job for a student !

pros:
Very engaged to society
Nice environment
Always seeking for new ways to improve (good long term vision)
cons:
Sometimes to bureaucratic
Change may happen slow because of it

pros: Nice team, great oppirtunity to learn, really interdisciplinary atmosphere, monthly usefull meetings with other researchers and phds

pros:
- Punctual payments
- Reasonable support and supplementary packages.
cons:
- Messy scheduling
- Not 100% determined workload. You might end up working more/less than the amount that you are being paid for.

pros:
Big university located in great city.
Good colleagues and students.
cons:
Offices, buildings and other infrastructures are not great
Quite bureaucratic

pros: Good salary, bonus and long paid holidays.
cons: PhD candidates are required to teach. It is annoying when even yourself didn't take that course before.

pros: Great research support. In general, the Netherlands academic sector has good compensation
cons: 60% assigned to teaching while heavily relying on research for tenure/promotion
